intro: Siphocampylus warmingii, commonly known as the golden bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of South America. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its showy, bell-shaped yellow flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in full sun to partial shade. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are upright and often branched. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
